references:
We repeat the experiments with four different temperature parameters Œ±=1,2,4,8ùõº1248\alpha=1,2,4,8italic_Œ± = 1 , 2 , 4 , 8, which allows us to assess the utility of the RAG models with different levels of item-fairness.
From Figure 3, we observe how effectively Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±, described in the Equation 2, controls the disparity of rankings.
For example, when Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is set to 4, we usually obtain a set of sampled rankings with EE-D¬Ø¬ØEE-D\overline{\text{EE-D}}over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG mostly in the range of [0.5, 0.8], and when Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± is set to 8, we often get a set of sampled rankings with EE-D¬Ø=1¬ØEE-D1\overline{\text{EE-D}}=1over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG = 1.
Refer to Appendix D to see the full description of the effect of Œ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± on the other metrics.

S5.T1.2.1.1.caption: Table 1: Each value in the table is the difference between the utility of a baseline (deterministic) RAG model and the average utility of a fairer RAG model at a specific fairness interval. Nonnegative differences are highlighted. Full results are listed in Appendix I.
references:
However, a closer look at the local trend offers a significant insight: RAG systems with fair ranking can often achieve higher system-effectiveness compared to models with deterministic rankers.
In Table 1, we divided the fairness levels into five intervals based on the normalized EE-D. As shown in the table and Appendix I, improving fairness to the level of EE-D¬Ø‚àà[0.8,1.0)¬ØEE-D0.81.0\overline{\text{EE-D}}\in[0.8,1.0)over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG ‚àà [ 0.8 , 1.0 ), and even EE-D¬Ø‚àà[0.6,0.8)¬ØEE-D0.60.8\overline{\text{EE-D}}\in[0.6,0.8)over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG ‚àà [ 0.6 , 0.8 ), can often enhance the utility of many RAG models across most LaMP tasks. For example, having EE-D¬Ø¬ØEE-D\overline{\text{EE-D}}over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG in the range of [0.8, 1.0) outperforms the baseline for all models in LaMP-2 and for seven out of nine models in LaMP tasks 4, 5, and 6.

However, a closer look at the local trend offers a significant insight: RAG systems with fair ranking can often achieve higher system-effectiveness compared to models with deterministic rankers.
In Table 1, we divided the fairness levels into five intervals based on the normalized EE-D. As shown in the table and Appendix I, improving fairness to the level of EE-D¬Ø‚àà[0.8,1.0)¬ØEE-D0.81.0\overline{\text{EE-D}}\in[0.8,1.0)over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG ‚àà [ 0.8 , 1.0 ), and even EE-D¬Ø‚àà[0.6,0.8)¬ØEE-D0.60.8\overline{\text{EE-D}}\in[0.6,0.8)over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG ‚àà [ 0.6 , 0.8 ), can often enhance the utility of many RAG models across most LaMP tasks. For example, having EE-D¬Ø¬ØEE-D\overline{\text{EE-D}}over¬Ø start_ARG EE-D end_ARG in the range of [0.8, 1.0) outperforms the baseline for all models in LaMP-2 and for seven out of nine models in LaMP tasks 4, 5, and 6.
